newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore electronic shares rally along with U.S..
newsitem.headline: Singapore electronic shares rally along with U.S..

text.p: Electronic shares in Singapore rose swiftly on Thursday morning, spurred by a bull run on Wall Street, dealers said.
At 0330 GMT, the SES electronics index was up 2.68 points, or 1.96 percent, at 139.56 after touching a new year high of 139.76.

Among the stocks fueling the index were multimedia Creative Technology, which hit a three-year high at S$33.20, Electronic Resources, which rose 11 cents to S$2.52 and Flextech Holdings which gained three cents to S$1.83.

"They are up on Wall Street's bullishness and anticipation that when the U.S. market improves, local firms, especially personal computer-related ones, would benefit from a pick up in orders," said a dealer with a local dealer said.
On Wednesday, U.S. technology stocks surged amid announcements of robust earnings, pushing the Nasdaq up a record 38.52 points to an unofficial close of 1,580.63.

Analysts were optimistic there would be a pickup in the second half of 1997 in Singapore's electronic sector, which accounts for about 58 percent of total domestic exports, after an insipid first half.
"The second half is looking more positive, particularly with some new orders coming in the third quarter," said investment analyst Pearly Yap at SocGen Crosby.
Among the stocks recommended were Advanced Systems Automation, Wong's Circuit, Elec & Eltek as well as peripheral stocks like Lung Kee Metals and Thakral.
Yap said there was good value in ASA, which could see a 50 percent earnings growth for the financial year ending March 1998.
"They have got their own proprietory technology and they are doing well. Orders have picked up," Yap said.
Flextech, now trading around S$1.83, up three cents, was seen as a trading buy by analysts who are expecting it to rally towards S$2.20 in about three months.
"This is because of the new businesses it is in," research house Fraser-AMMB said.
Fraser said its acquisitions of two business units of Texas Instruments would impact earnings positively.
